title: 107_hr970
content: SECTION 1. SAFE AND DRUG-FREE SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES. Amendment to Part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes changes to funding allocation for fiscal year 2002 and subsequent years. Subparts and sections are redesignated for clarity and organization. The Amendment to Part A of title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes redesignating subparts and sections for clarity and organization. "SEC. 4121. COMPREHENSIVE PREVENTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANTS." The Secretary is authorized to provide grants to States for prevention programs meeting high scientific standards. States must submit a plan detailing grant selection criteria, funding only well-documented programs, and disseminating research-based materials. The State educational agency must detail how they will disseminate research-based prevention models, provide technical assistance to local agencies, evaluate program implementation, measure results, ensure compliance with requirements, and provide assurances for funds received. The State educational agency must ensure local programs meet requirements, funds supplement other sources, and meet additional criteria as required by the Secretary. SEC. 4122 outlines the reservations and allocations of funds for each fiscal year, with funds reserved and allocated among states. If a state agency fails to develop a plan meeting requirements, funds will be reallocated to other states. Funds allocated must be used for implementing programs under this subpart. SEC. 4123 discusses the distribution of funds. Each State educational agency receiving funds under section 4004(2) must provide competitive grants to local educational agencies. Grants prioritize agencies with demonstrated need, support startup costs for prevention plans, and ensure equitable distribution. The State educational agency must provide grants to local educational agencies to support startup costs for prevention plans. Funds can be used for administrative expenses and to inform agencies about effective prevention approaches. "SEC. 4124. LOCAL AWARDS." To be eligible for a subgrant, a local educational agency must submit an application and a plan demonstrating how it will meet program requirements. The grant funds must be used for implementing prevention programs based on reliable research to address various issues and improve student performance. The subgrant program requires local educational agencies to implement prevention programs based on reliable research to address issues like violence, substance abuse, and academic performance. These programs must comprehensively address children's health, employ appropriate activities, assist in skill improvement, engage children actively, involve parents and the community in planning and implementation. The subgrant program requires local educational agencies to implement prevention programs based on reliable research to address issues like violence, substance abuse, and academic performance. These programs must involve better communication between children and adults, meaningful involvement of various stakeholders, high-quality staff training, measurable outcome goals, external technical support, and coordination of resources to support comprehensive prevention efforts. The subgrant program mandates local educational agencies to implement prevention programs based on research to address issues like violence, substance abuse, and academic performance. These programs require better communication, stakeholder involvement, staff training, outcome goals, technical support, and coordination of resources for comprehensive prevention efforts. Other resources available to the State will be utilized to support and sustain these prevention efforts.
